content.description: Zinc is a harder version of Overhang. It is to the right and goes directly up. There are crimps and pockets in the middle section that are small. This is the crux. Take your time to find the holds in this section and you should be good. There is a good rest at a ledge just below the top.
content.location: To the right of Overhang. It is a much harder variation.

content.description: Smiley is a simple climb with a variety of very good hand holds and foot holds. There are multiple ways to start this climb, the easiest being straight up the ledge or on the right of the ledge. The crack usually remains wet longer than the rest of the route after rain, but the climb is still doable without using the crack.
content.location: To the right of Cheese Grater and to the left of Root Canal.

content.description: Really easy slab climb with good hand and foot holds the whole way. Great for beginners that are learning to lead climb. The bolts are close enough together that no equipment (nuts, cams, etc.) other than quickdraws are needed. The climb also has two top anchors for top roping.
content.protection: Two anchors at the top with 3 leads.
content.location: To the left of Cheese Grater and to the right of Jaws.

content.description: Root Canal is one of the interesting climbs at Area 31. About halfway up the climb there is a hold that looks like a tooth, hence the name "Root Canal." There are multiple holds to point out in which make this climb easier. First being a side-pull down and to the left of the tooth. This side-pull can allow you to reach your hand alongside the tooth, although for taller people this is unnecessary. There is a slight overhang where two small, sharp under clings have to be used. It's a really awesome move to perform. A crimp above the overhang as well as a high left hand to the crack above the overhang are also key holds to this route.
content.location: To the right of Smiley and to the left of Overhang.

content.description: Overhang is a really nice climb that wears out your arms really fast. There are multiple ways to get over the overhang. If you are new to this route, having a spotter may be helpful. This will ensure that if you fall off the wall, you will not swing into your belayer or hit the ground. Many holds at the beginning are heavily chalked and show the easiest way to go. Depending on the way you go, there is a traverse from the left to right underneath the overhang and it is key to make sure you don't get your feet too high. At the top, there are two main ways to go, straight up or to the right.
content.location: To the right of Root Canal. It is the most right of all the climbs. It is next to one of the ways to get to the bottom of all climbs.

content.description: Cheese Grater has sharp, small holds the whole way up. There are plenty of them, but the climb is still challenging. There is the direct path and the alternative path. Both of them are a challenge.
content.location: To the right of Slab and to the left of Smiley.

content.description: Jeff's Corner is a relatively easy route that is very interesting. There is a small overhang where the climber has to overcome with nice finger holds in a crack. You can also use the tree and the rock to chimney climb if you really want to. There are different ways to go about this climb, whether you go up the corner or start underneath the overhang and go straight up for a harder challenge.
content.location: Walk farther to the left from Jaws. There is a huge tree that is right against the wall.

content.description: Start on a pretty slopey hold. Traverse right to a really good pocket and match. From there, reach out right to a side pull. Move feet to a triangle sticking out. Put left hand in the side pull as well. Transfer weight from left side to right side. This is the crux section. Reach out right to the last hold. It is a bit slopey. Do not use the top ledge for this boulder problem. Otherwise it is a V0.
content.location: It is the bottom portion of Smiley.

content.description: Jaws is a really nice slab climb with not many foot holds or hand holds. It is best to go straight up or to the right, because the farther left you go, the more vegetation. Be careful when coming down (especially when wet), because the crevice on the bottom will suck you in. Hence the name.

This area is generally used as the "main area." There are benches at the bottom and has the most recreational space between all of the areas. There are many sets of bolts that are easily accessible and safe to use. If you have the proper slings, you can avoid your rope rubbing on the rock. This area has climbs for people of all difficulty, with routes ranging from 5.3 to 5.10. This is also the only area that includes a route used for sport climbing.
